'''Webster's''' ('''Samuel Webster & Sons Limited'''), was a [[brewery]] founded in 1838 by Samuel Webster which operated at the Fountain Head Brewery in [[Halifax, West Yorkshire|Halifax]] in the [[West Riding of Yorkshire]], England until 1996. Its two most famous brands, Webster's ''Green Label'', a [[mild ale|light mild]], and ''Yorkshire Bitter'' continue to be sold, although the [[cask conditioned]] versions were discontinued in 2010. Silvan Brands have owned the company since 2003 when they bought it from [[Scottish & Newcastle]]. The company's [[tied house|tied estate]] concentrated on its Halifax heartland, and then spread throughout [[West Yorkshire]]. The brand spread to other areas of the [[United Kingdom]] following the company's takeover by the national brewer [[Watney Mann]] in 1972, and by the 1980s Webster's beers were available across the country. Perhaps their most famous advertising slogan was 'Drives out the northern thirst'. Webster's was also known for its sponsorship of numerous sporting events throughout the 1980s and early 1990s, particularly [[cricket]] and horse racing.
The brewery was closed with the loss of hundreds of jobs due to overcapacity in the brewing industry, but also lower sales as a result of diminished marketing support for the Webster's brand after it was acquired by [[Courage Brewery]] as part of its takeover of the [[Grand Metropolitan]] beer brands. After the brewery's closure, Webster's branded beers were initially brewed at the [[John Smith's Brewery]] in [[Tadcaster]], and were subsequently moved to the Thomas Hardy Brewery at [[Burtonwood]] in 2004. The former brewery site has since been converted into a housing estate, the [[Grade II]] listed Old Maltings building has been converted into an adult learning centre and the former visitor's centre, located in a seventeeth century building, into a pub called Long Can Hall. Some public houses in the Halifax area still retain Webster's branding, although very few still sell Webster's beers.
==History== ===Origins: 1838-1900=== [[File:Fountainhead.jpg|thumb|The Old Maltings, since converted into an adult learning centre.]] Samuel Webster (1813â1872) was born in [[Ovenden]], a small village located about 2 mi from Halifax town centre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://freepages.history.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~calderdalecompanion/w.html#w1644 |title=Malcolm Bull's Calderdale Companion: W |publisher=Freepages.history.rootsweb.ancestry.com |date= |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> He was the eldest of seven brothers born into a [[Congregationalist]] family; his father was a farmer who owned 10 [[acre]]s of land.<ref>[http://freepages.history.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~calderdalecompanion/w.html#w2700 Malcolm Bull's Calderdale Companion: W<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Webster acquired the small Fountain Head Brewery in Ovenden Wood in 1838 when he was just 25, and opened an office in Union Cross Yard, Halifax.<ref name="nationalarchives.gov.uk">[http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/A2A/records.aspx?cat=203-wyc1234&cid=-1#-1 The National Archives | Access to Archives<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The site had been chosen for its [[Pennine]] spring which would provide the water used to brew Webster's products until the brewery's closure. The water was rich in [[magnesium sulphate]], which added bitterness to the [[beer]], and provided it with a dry finish.<ref>{{cite web|author=University of Leicester |url=http://guardian.chadwyck.co.uk.ezproxy.lib.le.ac.uk/guardian/advancedSearchDisplayRecord.do?articleWords=webster's%20bitter&articleWordsContaining=exact&publication=BOTH&section=&sortType=reverseChronological&pageSize=25&pageNum=1&index=1 |title=EZProxy |publisher=Guardian.chadwyck.co.uk.ezproxy.lib.le.ac.uk |date=2008-04-29 |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=j-Xu07p3cKwC&pg=PA244&dq=%22webster's+yorkshire+bitter%22&hl=en&ei=ijfETcjKOpC38gOY8rXcAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CE4Q6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=%22webster's%20yorkshire%20bitter%22&f=false |title=Nature's building blocks: an A-Z ... â Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> Initially only supplying the free trade (public houses not tied to one particular brewer), by 1845 Webster had bought his first public house.<ref name="nationalarchives.gov.uk"/> By 1848 the firm had earned itself a reputation as the premier brewer in the [[north of England]], although it ought to be noted that brewers in the north tended to very small at this time.<ref name="nationalarchives.gov.uk"/> In 1860 he was joined in [[partnership]] by his three sons, Isaac, George Henry and Samuel Green, and the firm began trading as Samuel Webster & Sons.<ref>The Brewing industry: a guide to historical records By Lesley Richmond, Alison Turton, p356</ref> After Webster's death in 1872 his sons continued the family business.<ref>[http://freepages.history.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~calderdalecompanion/w.html#w141 Malcolm Bull's Calderdale Companion: W<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In 1873, increasing demand led the company to extend and redevelop the brewery.<ref name="nationalarchives.gov.uk"/> The firm also imported and sold wines and cigars, in addition to its brewing business.<ref>[http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/A2A/records.aspx?cat=203-wyc1234&cid=7#7 The National Archives | Access to Archives<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
By 1880 the company had purchased its 100th [[tied house]].<ref name=Nat>{{cite web |url= http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/A2A/records.aspx?cat=203-wyc1234&cid=-1#-1 |title=The National Archives | SAMUEL WEBSTER AND SONS LTD, FOUNTAIN HEAD BREWERY, OVENDEN, BREWERS, ADDITIONAL RECORDS |date=17 August 2004 |author=Samuel Webster and Sons Ltd |publisher=nationalarchives.gov.uk |accessdate=15 April 2011}}</ref> In March 1890 Samuel Webster & Sons became a [[registered company]], with Â£175,000 (Â£17.5 million in 2010) of capital, and Isaac Webster, Samuel's eldest son, its first chairman.<ref name="nationalarchives.gov.uk"/><ref>COMMERCIAL & MARKETS . Liverpool Mercury etc (Liverpool, England), Monday, 24 March 1890; Issue 13169.</ref> That same year the brewery was connected to the railway network, facilitating transportation of their products.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.halifaxtown.co.uk/halifax_history_blog/post/1224/title/our_early_railways.htm Halifax History Blog > Halifax Town, Calderdale, West Yorkshire<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In 1892 net profit was Â£20,000 (Â£2 million).<ref>COMMERCIAL REPORTS . The Leeds Mercury (Leeds, England), Tuesday, 26 January 1892; Issue 16787</ref> In 1896 the company took over H & T T Ormerod of [[Brighouse]], West Yorkshire which could trace its origins back to 1760, and the Northgate Hotel in Halifax.<ref name="richmond357">The Brewing industry: a guide to historical records By Lesley Richmond, Alison Turton, p357</ref><ref name="brighouseecho1">[http://www.brighouseecho.co.uk/community/echoes-of-the-past/toast_to_the_pioneer_brewers_1_2983515 Toast to the pioneer brewers - Echoes of the Past - Brighouse Echo<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Isaac Webster died in 1899, leaving an estate of Â£87,454 (Â£9 million).<ref>Births, Deaths, Marriages and Obituaries . The Morning Post (London, England), Saturday, 17 June 1899; pg. 5; Issue 39636. 19th Century British Library Newspapers: Part II.</ref> In 1900 the Maltings building was built as part of a Â£10,000 (Â£1 million) development project.<ref>http://www.catalogue.wyjs.org.uk/Record.aspx?src=CalmView.Catalog&id=WYAS1998&pos=175</ref> It was designed by [[William Chambers (architect)|William Chambers]], and remains a landmark of the Ovenden valley.<ref>[http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=447632 Detailed Record<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> By this time the company's office had moved to 57 Northgate, Halifax.<ref>[http://freepages.history.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~calderdalecompanion/w.html#w1644 Malcolm Bull's Calderdale Companion: W<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> At the turn of the century [[Calderdale]] could boast 25 breweries.<ref name="brighouseecho1"/>
===20th-century consolidation=== The [[temperance]] movement of the late nineteenth and early twentieth century, and emergency laws aimed at restricting drinking during the [[First World War]] created difficult trading conditions for brewers.<ref>[http://www.westernfrontassociation.com/component/content/article/160-life-on-the-home-front/1591-lloyd-georges-beer-or-when-it-was-illegal-to-buy-your-round.html âLloyd George's Beer' or When It Was Illegal to Buy Your Round<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In 1919 net profit was reported at Â£22,325 (Â£900,000 at 2010 prices).<ref>The Manchester Guardian (1901-1959) [Manchester (UK)] 7 March 1919: 9.</ref> Samuel Wentworth Webster, a director of the company and grandson of the founder, died in 1928 with a [[personalty]] of Â£45,000 (Â£2.2 million in 2010).<ref>The Times, 28 August 1928</ref> In 1929, the company's entire stock of properties, land and brewery buildings was valued at Â£468,833 (Â£23.2 million in 2010).<ref>http://www.catalogue.wyjs.org.uk/Record.aspx?src=CalmView.Catalog&id=WYAS4031&pos=181</ref> The company took over Joseph Stocks of Halifax in December 1932, which could trace its origins back to 1790.<ref name="brighouseecho1"/> By the 1950s only four Calderdale breweries survived: Webster's, Ramsden's, Whitaker's and Fielding's.<ref name="brighouseecho1"/> In 1957 Webster's took over John Ainley & Sons of [[Huddersfield]] and Woodhead Brothers of [[Elland]], near Halifax, a mineral water manufacturer.<ref name="richmond357"/> By 1958 the Northgate offices were proving insufficient for the brewery's increasing needs, and new offices were built on the Ovenden Wood site.<ref name="Samuel Webster pg. 2">Samuel Webster & Sons Ltd. The Financial Times (London, England), Monday, 8 April 1957; p. 2; Edition 21,133.</ref> The spring which was the sole source of water for the brewery was repeatedly dammed in order to ensure a continuous supply during the summer months.<ref>Samuel Webster & Sons, Ltd. The Financial Times (London, England), Thursday, 3 March 1960; p. 6; Edition 22,024</ref> In 1960 the maltings was responsible for malt production of 6000 quarters (8000 kilograms) per annum, however it was closed shortly afterwards as it could no longer supply the brewery's increasing demand for malt.<ref>The Guardian (1959-2003) [London (UK)] 11 August 1960: 13.</ref> In 1961 Webster's bought Daniel Fielding & Sons of Halifax, which added 19 public houses to their tied estate.<ref>SAMUEL WEBSTER & SONS LTD.: A RECORD TRADING YEAR PLANS FOR INCREASING CAPACITY MR J R G MARCHETTI'S STATEMENT The Guardian (1959-2003) [London (UK)] 08 Mar 1963: 18.</ref> The same year the company sought out partnership with the national brewer [[Watney Mann]] in order to gain technical knowledge.<ref name="Samuel Webster 2011">"Samuel Webster & Sons, Limited." Financial Times [London, England] 3 Mar. 1961: 4. Financial Times. Web. 19 August 2011.</ref> In return, Webster's brewed and sold the [[brewery conditioned]] ''Watney's Red Barrel'' [[ale]] throughout their tied estate.<ref name="Samuel Webster 2011"/> In 1962 a reciprocal trading agreement was reached with [[Ind Coope]]'s North East division which saw Webster's houses stock [[lager]] for the first time. That same year the group won the contract to bottle ''[[Tuborg]]'' for West Yorkshire.<ref>SAMUEL WEBSTER & SONS LTD.: A RECORD TRADING YEAR PLANS FOR INCREASING CAPACITY MR J R G MARCHETTI'S STATEMENT The Guardian (1959-2003) [London (UK)] 8 March 1963: 18.</ref> In 1966 a friendly takeover of the [[Bradford]] brewers J. Hey & Company Limited added 73 public houses to their estate.<ref>The Times Tuesday, 14 March 1967; p. 16; Issue 56889; col A</ref> Webster's was valued at Â£3.3 million, and J. Hey valued at Â£1 million.<ref name="DECCA'S P.C">Boardroom news: DECCA'S 'SPLENDID' RESULTS SQUEEZE SHOULD BENEFIT TELEFUSION SCHWEPPES' PROFITS LEAP BY 15 P.C The Guardian (1959-2003) [London (UK)] 14 September 1966: 12.</ref> The combined group had assets of over Â£4.5 million (Â£65 million in 2010 prices).<ref name="DECCA'S P.C"/> Throughout the 1960s and early 70s, the company had never been more successful, owing its continued success to consolidation in the industry, a good product and successful marketing.<ref name="Consultancy pg. 22">Brewery gets taste for new technique Consultancy (Business and Finance) The Times Monday, 25 March 1968; p. 22; Issue 57209; col A</ref> The [[social club]] trade was incredibly important to the company, accounting for half of 1968's Â£5 million turnover.<ref name="Consultancy pg. 22"/> In 1969 with the takeover and closure of Richard Whitaker & Sons by [[Whitbread]] Webster's became the last company still brewing in the Calderdale area.<ref>[http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/a2a/records.aspx?cat=203-whi&cid=-1#-1 The National Archives | Access to Archives<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The company's flamboyant chairman from 1950 and the grandson of Isaac Webster, John "Tommy" Roderick Giulio Marchetti died in 1969.<ref name="ancestry1">[http://freepages.history.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~calderdalecompanion/m.html Malcolm Bull's Calderdale Companion: M<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
By 1967 Watney Mann owned 18.4 per cent of the company, and Webster's had a market capitalization of Â£6 million (Â£85 million in 2010 prices) and owned 320 public houses and 12 [[off license]]s.<ref>"The protectors and the protected." Economist [London, England] 2 December 1967: 991+. The Economist Historical Archive 1843â2006. Web. 19 August 2011.</ref><ref> Investors chronicle and stock exchange gazette, Volume 2, Part 2, 1967, p209</ref> Watney Mann had gradually increased their share to 27.1 per cent by 1972 when it initiated a takeover of the rest of the company.<ref>The economist, Volume 225, Issue 3</ref> Samuel Webster & Sons owned around 280 tied houses, and was offered Â£18 million for the 73 per cent of the company that Watney did not already own.<ref>Â£359m bid for Watney Mann (News) By A Goodrick-Clarke and Andrew Wilson. The Times Saturday, 11 March 1972; p. 1; Issue 58424; col C</ref> The Watney Mann offer valued the entire company at almost Â£250 million in 2010 prices.<ref>[http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/education/inflation/calculator/flash/index.htm Bank of England | Education | Inflation | Inflation Calculator<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The takeover was a friendly one, and dependent upon the agreement of the Webster family, who owned 20 per cent of the company.<ref name="Andrew Wilson pg. 17">Watney takeover puts Â£24m value on brewery (Business and Finance) By Andrew Wilson. The Times Tuesday, 29 February 1972; p. 17; Issue 58414; col E</ref> [[Geoffrey Hirst]] was also present on the board of directors.<ref>World who's who in commerce and industry, Volume 15, 1968, p640</ref> Watney Mann was motivated by an increase to their pub estate (the number of pubs they owned).<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=CtwSAQAAMAAJ&q=%22Webster's+Brewery%22+-inpublisher:icon&dq=%22Webster's+Brewery%22+-inpublisher:icon&cd=5 |title=The death of the English pub â Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=2010-10-19 |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref><ref>The Times Tuesday, 13 January 1970; p. 28; Issue 57766; col A</ref> Following the takeover, Webster's continued as a regional subsidiary of the Watney Mann brewing empire, responsible for Yorkshire, [[Humberside]], north [[Derbyshire]] and north [[Nottinghamshire]].<ref>The Guardian (1959-2003) [London (UK)] 21 May 1981: 21.</ref> The takeover was a great boon for Webster's as Watney Mann invested heavily in the brewery, commissioning a new brewhouse in 1973, and the Webster's brands enjoyed increased distribution nationally.<ref name="nationalarchives.gov.uk"/> That same year, Watney Mann itself was taken over by [[Grand Metropolitan]]. Sales for 1976-77 were Â£24.2 million against Â£21.9 million the previous year; pre-tax profit was Â£3.15 million versus Â£3.39 million.<ref>The Times, 2 March 1978, p22</ref> In 1979 a new Â£6 million lager plant was started, initially brewing ''[[Holsten Brewery|Holsten]]''.<ref name=Nat/><ref>United Press International 4 July 1984, Wednesday, AM cycle</ref> That year, Webster's employed 1500 people in the production, distribution and retailing of beers, wines and spirits throughout Yorkshire.<ref>Management services, Volume 29, 1979</ref>
[[File:Longcan.jpg|thumb|Long Can Hall. Built in 1637, it served as the brewery visitor's centre from 1986 until 1996.]] In 1980 the company reported a pre tax profit of Â£3.65 million (Â£12.2 million in 2010 prices) against sales of Â£46.8 million (Â£160 million).<ref>Lex, See. "Grand Met Warns on Tax Threat." Financial Times [London, England] 11 February 1981: 16. Financial Times. Web. 12 September 2011.</ref> During the early 1980s, Webster's had beer production volumes of around 400,000 barrels per annum, and the brewery employed around 600 people.<ref>The Guardian (1959-2003) [London (UK)] 20 January 1983: 21.</ref> The early 1980s saw the "gradual transformation" of Webster's into a national brand.<ref>European Cases in Strategic Management By John Hendry, Tony Eccles, p246-7</ref> At the same time, the brewery was described as "wonderfully traditional" and had open fermentation vessels, mash tuns and copper brewing vessels.<ref>[http://www.morningadvertiser.co.uk/General-News/On-the-trail-of-old-favourites2 On the trail of old favourites<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Production of ''[[Budweiser]]'' began in 1984. In that year Webster's tied estate consisted of 7 per cent of Yorkshire's pubs, compared with [[John Smith's]] 15 per cent and [[Tetley's Brewery|Tetley's]] 14 per cent. As a result the company remained dependent on the free trade for the majority of its sales.<ref name=warc>[http://www.warc.com/Content/ContentViewer.aspx?MasterContentRef=8dec4884-9ccc-4d44-986f-c5416fd4c21a&q=webster Webster] warc.com {{subscription required}}</ref> In 1985 Grand Met merged the Wilson Brewery of [[Manchester]] (which Watney Mann had bought in 1960) with Webster's to form Samuel Webster and Wilsons Ltd.<ref name=Nat/> In 1986 the Wilsons Brewery was closed down with the loss of 237 jobs and production of ''Wilsons Original Bitter'' and ''Wilsons Mild'' was moved to Halifax.<ref>Wood, Lisa. "Brewery Closure to Hit 237 Jobs." Financial Times [London, England] 9 May 1986: 8. Financial Times. Web. 19 August 2011.</ref> By 1987 brewery capacity was extended from 1 million barrels a year to 1.3 million barrels, and by 1988 Webster's was supplying around 1000 pubs in the [[north of England]], and as far afield as [[Deganwy]] in North Wales.<ref>http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/50860/pages/3497/page.pdf</ref> Also in 1988 the historic Long Can Hall was purchased to serve as the brewery's visitor's centre. In 1989 the Old Maltings was converted into brewery offices.<ref>A brief guide to the industrial heritage of West Yorkshire, Thompson, p15</ref> As part of it disposal of non-core assets, Grand Met sold Webster's to [[Scottish & Newcastle|Courage]] in 1990.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=QqnvNsgas20C&pg=PA691&lpg=PA691&dq=grand+metropolitan+webster's&source=bl&ots=b61MnO1UDH&sig=Lk4EQQHmm7sB3NB-ATJ4L4XJzG0&hl=en&ei=DaepTe6EBJGyhAeY-JDZCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CBkQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=A history of beer and brewing â Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> By that year Webster's had an annual revenue of around Â£100 million and claimed 7 per cent of the national bitter market.<ref name=Nat/><ref name="ReferenceA">Webster vies for lager youth, Campaign, 16 November 1990</ref> The vast proportion of the Fountain Head Brewery's 1.3 million barrel capacity was dedicated to brewing Webster's and Wilsons ales. However Courage also owned the more popular John Smith's ale brand, and Webster's was deprioritized.<ref>John Smith's Bitter: Changing the agenda for bitter advertising</ref><ref>Enter a new pub giant as Courage swallows GrandMet breweries Outlook The Guardian (Manchester) 14 March 1990; Roger Cowe; p. 10</ref> ''John Smith's'' was the fourth best selling bitter in the country in 1990 and ''Webster's'' the sixth, so the decision was an obvious one.<ref>Marketing 24 May 1990 Neilsen Brand Index: The ones that got away</ref> The brands suffered further after the [[Scottish & Newcastle]] takeover of Courage, as S&N already owned a large number of ale brands, and a third Yorkshire bitter brand in [[Theakston Brewery|Theakstons]]. Despite early success when it had been the only major ale brand in a national brewer's portfolio, in 1996 ''[[Scotland on Sunday]]'' described the beer as "staid" and argued that it "never caught on outside its Yorkshire heartland."<ref name="Sunday 1996">Big beer rolls back the barrel, Scotland on Sunday, 21 January 1996, Sunday</ref> With the withdrawal of ''Webster's'' marketing support, ''John Smith's'' was outselling it three to one by 1996.<ref name="Sunday 1996"/>
===Closure=== In 1991 it was speculated that the brewery would be closed down due to overcapacity in the brewing industry.<ref name="The Guardian p. 9">1,400 Courage jobs to go The Guardian (Manchester) 8 August 1991; FINANCIAL STAFF; p. 9</ref> The brewery's bottling line was closed in 1991, with the loss of 54 jobs, but the brewery itself survived for another five years.<ref name="The Guardian p. 9"/> At the time of its closure in November 1996, the brewery had employed 184 people on a site that had extended to ten [[hectare]]s.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/scottish--newcastle-to-cut-1600-brewing-jobs-1324420.html |title=Scottish & Newcastle to cut 1,600 brewing jobs â Business, News â The Independent |author=Nigel Cope|work=[[The Independent]] |date=17 January 1996 |publisher=[[Independent News & Media|INM]] |location=[[London, UK|London]] |issn=0951-9467 |oclc=185201487 |accessdate=15 April 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.gleesonstrategicland.co.uk/fountainheadbrewary.asp Gleeson Strategic Land - Fountainhead Brewary - Part of the MJ Gleeson Group of Companies<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> As well as Webster's and Wilson's beers, the brewery had been producing the lager brands ''[[Foster's Lager|Foster's]]'' and ''[[Molson]]''.<ref>Scottish & Newcastle to cut 1,600 brewing jobs, The Independent, 17 January 1996</ref> The brewery had been running at "well below" 50 per cent of its 1.3 million barrel capacity which was deemed "unsustainable".<ref>http://www.competition-commission.org.uk/rep_pub/reports/1990/fulltext/288c5.pdf</ref><ref>Oram, Roderick. "S&N Sheds 1,600 Jobs in Courage Integration." Financial Times [London, England] 17 January 1996: 28. Financial Times. Web. 19 August 2011.</ref> Although productivity per employee had been the highest of any of Scottish & Newcastle's brewing plants it was argued that the brewery would have required substantial investment if it was to remain competitive.<ref>Cowe, Roger. The Guardian (1959-2003) [London (UK)] 17 January 1996: 16.</ref><ref>MPs CHALLENGE BREWERY JOB CUTS, Press Association, 17 January 1996, Wednesday</ref> The [[Campaign for Real Ale]] argued that the closure of the brewery could have been avoided if the Webster's and Wilsons brands had been better managed.<ref>1,600 BREWERY JOBS FACE AXE, Press Association, 16 January 1996, Tuesday</ref> The site is now taken up by residential housing, whilst the Grade II [[listed building|listed]] Long Can Hall has been converted into a restaurant and the Grade II listed Old Maltings building has been converted into an adult learning centre.<ref name="halifaxcourier2">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.halifaxcourier.co.uk/news/business/bringing_a_history_of_brewing_back_to_life_1_1941260 |title=Bringing a history of brewing back to life â Business |publisher=Halifax Courier |date= 13 November 2009|accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> Following the closure, Webster's beers were initially brewed at Scottish Courage's John Smith's Brewery in [[Tadcaster]], but were subsequently moved to the Thomas Hardy Brewery at [[Burtonwood]] in 2004.<ref>http://www.spbw.com/magazine/PiH%2097.pdf</ref> [[Scottish & Newcastle]] continued to provide funding for a former employees' annual [[Christmas lunch]] until 2003, when the Webster's brands were sold to Silvan Brands as part of the firm's strategy of disposing of non-core brands.<ref>London Stock Exchange Aggregated Regulatory News Service (ARNS) 19 February 2008 Tuesday 2:01 AM GMT Scot.& Newcastle Final Results</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.halifaxcourier.co.uk/news/local/calderdale_life_wee_sam_lunch_proves_to_be_as_popular_as_ever_1_1943290 |title=Calderdale Life: Wee Sam lunch proves to be as popular as ever â Local |publisher=Halifax Courier |date=28 December 2008 |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref><ref>[http://www.ipo.gov.uk/t-find-number?detailsrequested=H&trademark=1190241 Intellectual Property Office - Results<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The chairman Brian Stewart remarked following the disposal that "''Webster's'' was a brand that did not have a strong brand franchise. What has happened is that brands [which] consumers demand are still here - like ''Courage'', ''Newcastle Exhibition'' and ''McEwan's''."<ref>The Sunday Herald 7 July 2002 McEwan's still best buy says S&N chairman</ref> Heineken UK have since sold the Courage and McEwan's brands to [[Wells & Youngs]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-business-15167251 | work=BBC News | title=Brewer buys McEwan's and Younger's Scottish ales | date=4 October 2011}}</ref>
==Brands== ===Main=== [[File:The Old Cock Inn, Old Cock Yard, Halifax - geograph.org.uk - 272311.jpg|thumb|left|''The Old Cock Inn'', Halifax, dates from 1580 and was the flagship Webster's public house. Annual general meetings by the company's directors were held there until the company's takeover. The [[Halifax (United Kingdom bank)|Halifax]] bank was founded there in 1853.]]
Launched in 1928, by the 1950s the bottled light mild ''Green Label'' (4.2 per cent ABV) was Webster's most popular beer.<ref>Samuel Webster & SonsThe Financial Times (London, England),Monday, April 09, 1956; pg. 7; Edition 20,825 (534 words) </ref><ref name="blogspot1959">[http://barclayperkins.blogspot.com/2011/11/samuel-webster-beers-1959-1989.html Shut up about Barclay Perkins: Samuel Webster beers 1959 - 1989<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> At this time, bottled beers accounted for around half of all beer sales at the brewery, which reflected the national trend.<ref name="Samuel Webster pg. 7">Samuel Webster & Sons. The Financial Times (London, England), Monday, 9 April 1956; p. 7; Edition 20,825.</ref> Due to its popularity, ''Green Label'' was introduced as a keg beer in 1974, replacing ''Webster's Best''.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2003/sep/24/thefiver.sport?INTCMP=SRCH | location=London | work=The Guardian | first1=Scott | last1=Murray | first2=Lawrence | last2=Booth | title=Punishment, and Rankings | date=24 September 2003}}</ref><ref>[http://www.bierdeckelsammler.net/en/brewery/2537 Samuel Webster & Sons Ltd, HX2 0TL Halifax :: bierdeckelsammler.net :: bierdeckel.info :: Bier - Beer - Pivo, Bierdeckel - Beermats - Coasters<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It was made with [[Styrian Goldings]] [[hop (plant)|hop]]s.<ref>[http://www.petespintpot.co.uk/hops.html Hops<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''Pennine Bitter'' was introduced in April 1963 as Webster's first bitter brand as the style gained in popularity.<ref name="halifaxcourier3">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.halifaxcourier.co.uk/community/your-say/letters-and-emails/the_origins_of_webster_s_floral_pennine_bitter_1_3232198?commentssort=1 |title=The origins of Websterâs âfloralâ Pennine Bitter â Letters and Emails |publisher=Halifax Courier |date=2011-03-30 |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> It was a high quality product and slightly stronger than most of its rivals.<ref name="halifaxcourier3"/> It had a floral character as a result of the hops used, which were likely a variety of [[Kent]] [[Goldings]] and despite its name was created in the style of a Kentish bitter.<ref name="halifaxcourier3"/> ''Green Label'' light mild had such a strong following in the Halifax area that it was not until the 1970s that ''Pennine Bitter'' was made generally available there.<ref name="halifaxcourier3"/> "Pennine light mild" was a popular style unique to the [[Heavy Woollen District]]; other popular brands included ''Timothy Taylor Golden Best'' and ''Tetley Falstaff'' (which was previously brewed by Ramsden's of Halifax prior to their takeover by Tetley).<ref>[http://www.universitycaterer.co.uk/micro/carlsberg/brands.htm Carlsberg-Tetley<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> By the 1970s, ''Pennine Bitter'' and ''Green Label'' were firmly established as the predominant Webster's brands. In 1984 ''Green Label'' sold 90,000 barrels in Yorkshire alone.<ref name=warc/>
''Webster's Yorkshire Bitter'' (3.8 per cent ABV) was launched in the summer of 1982 in both cask and keg form, replacing ''Webster's Pennine Bitter'' as their predominant bitter brand, as it was rapidly declining in popularity due to it being perceived as an "old man beer", its bitterness and its availability in the by then unfashionable keg dispense.<ref>[http://www.huntscamra.org.uk/news/ot133-years-ago.asp Huntingdonshire CAMRA, Opening Times 133<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>Watch out for Webbo!: How advertising helped build a brand â and a brewery, Institute of Practitioners in Advertising: IPA Effectiveness Awards, 1984</ref> By 1984 Grand Metropolitan had transformed ''Yorkshire Bitter'' into a "massive" national brand, available in the company's 5,000 tied houses and 15,000 free houses.<ref>[http://tobaccodocuments.org/ti/TIWA0003704-3760.html?zoom=750&ocr_position=above_foramatted&start_page=1&end_page=57 Grand Metropolitan Annual Report 1984<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.morningadvertiser.co.uk/General-News/On-the-trail-of-old-favourites On the trail of old favourites<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It was marketed as their response to the growing popularity of "Yorkshire bitter" in the [[south of England]], particularly ''John Smith's'', but also ''Tetley'' and ''Stones''. ''Webster's Yorkshire Bitter'' was the most popular off trade bitter by 1985 with 18 per cent of the market.<ref>[http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=_OgdAQAAMAAJ&q=webster's+yorkshire+bitter&dq=webster's+yorkshire+bitter&hl=en&ei=1EeOTtbQE8Wp0QXGvq0q&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CEIQ6AEwAQ Marketing - Institute of Marketing and Sales Management - Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>The Grocer 12 April 1986 SECTION: Pg. 33</ref> It had become the highest selling bitter in the south of England and the fifth best selling bitter nationally by 1989, helped not least in part by its competitive price.<ref>Allied's Third Force in Scotland / Acquisition of Drybrough and Co from Grand Metropolitan, The Guardian, 10 January 1987</ref><ref>The Top Ten, Campaign, 26 May 1989</ref><ref>[http://www.executivesonline.co.uk/about_us/manager_case_studies/chris_k Chris K: Interactive Marketer and Entrepreneurial Leader<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The beer was not without its critics, with the 1990 ''[[Good Beer Guide]]'' describing it as ''"golden [in] colour, weak flavour[ed], reminiscent of a poor quality home brew â worty, bland, cloying, with a dirty finish on the tongue."'' <ref>GOOD BEER GUIDE IS ENTHUSIASTIC, PUNCHY, SOMETIMES ACID..., Press Association, 23 October 1989</ref> In 1993 ''Yorkshire Bitter'' was reduced from 3.8 per cent [[alcohol by volume]] to 3.5 per cent [[ABV]] in order to save money on duty.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/big-brewers-cut-strength-of-top-beers-industry-set-for-clash-with-government-over-alleged-losses-caused-by-change-in-way-excise-duty-is-calculated-1490182.html | location=London | work=The Independent | first=John | last=Shephard | title=Big brewers cut strength of top beers: Industry set for clash with Government over alleged losses caused by change in way excise duty is calculated | date=1993-06-07}}</ref> In 1994 the beer journalist [[Michael Jackson (writer)|Michael Jackson]] described Webster's beers as "light" and "faintly oily".<ref>The Simon & Schuster pocket guide to beer, p110</ref> That same year ''Webster's Yorkshire Bitter'' won Gold at the [[Brewing Industry International Awards]] in the 2.5-3.8 per cent ABV keg ale category.<ref>[http://www.brewingawards.org/articles_39_10.html Brewing Awards - Welcome to Brewing Awards<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
When Scottish & Newcastle acquired the [[John Smith's]] and Webster's bitter brands as part of their takeover of Courage in 1995, the less popular Webster's brands were deprioritized, and virtually all marketing support ceased.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.marketingweek.co.uk/home/scottish-courage-clears-out-brands/2014118.article |title=Scottish Courage clears out brands | Archive |publisher=Marketing Week |date=1996-02-09 |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> Since then, the Webster's brands have occupied the "value" end of the market.<ref>Off Licence News 12 November 1999 Brewer's troop</ref> In 1995-96, ''Yorkshire Bitter'' was still among the twenty five highest-selling beers in the UK, accounting for 0.8 per cent of all beer Webster's pack given an update</ref> Between 2001 and 2007 sales declined from 80,000 to 40,000 barrels per year, and [[Roger Protz]] has described the brand as "almost redundant.".<ref -->]</ref> The production of cask conditioned Webster's beer was ended in 2010.<ref>Good Beer Guide 2011, p694</ref> ''Green Label'' (3.2 per cent ABV) remains available in [[kegs]] and ''Yorkshire Bitter'' (3.5 per cent ABV) is available in kegs and 500 ml cans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ratebeer.com/beer/websters-yorkshire-bitter/15042/ |title=Websters Yorkshire Bitter ===Minor=== In 1955 Webster's introduced the bottled ''Sam Brown Ale'' (2.8 per cent ABV), although its strength was upped to 3.4 per cent ABV by the 1980s.<ref name="Samuel Webster pg. 7" /> The following year Webster's launched bottled ''Velvet Stout'' (2.9 per cent ABV) as a competitor to ''[[Mackeson Stout]]''.<ref name="Samuel Webster pg. 2"/><ref>[http://barclayperkins.blogspot.com/search?q=samuel+webster Shut up about Barclay Perkins: Search results for samuel webster<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> By the 1980s its strength had been increased to 4.2 per cent ABV, making it more of a competitor to ''Guinness''. Data indicates that the Webster's range in the 1950s was watery.<ref name="blogspot1959"/> The bottled beer brands were discontinued following the closure of the Webster's bottling plant in 1991. In 1983 a ''Webster's Dark Mild'', brewed to OG 1031.0, was launched in both cask and keg form, and was available until the early 1990s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huntscamra.org.uk/news/ot135-years-ago.asp |title=Huntingdonshire CAMRA, Opening Times 135 |publisher=Huntscamra.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beermad.org.uk/brewery/1028 |title=Webster's: brewery detail from |publisher=Beermad |date= |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> During the 1970s ''Webster's Reserve'' was available, a strong draught keg beer. It was replaced in the mid 1980s by cask conditioned ''Samuel Websters Choice'' (4.6 per cent ABV), which was itself discontinued around 1992. Only pubs which were deemed to keep the best cellar conditions were allowed to sell it.<ref>[http://www.halifaxcourier.co.uk/news/local/welcome_to_the_brewery_in_a_shoebox_1_1972942 Welcome to the brewery in a shoebox - Local - Halifax Courier<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In 1988 a commemorative beer was brewed to celebrate the 150th anniversary of the brewery.<ref name="freepages.history.rootsweb.ancestry.com">[http://freepages.history.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~calderdalecompanion/ph381.html Malcolm Bull's Calderdale Companion: Photograph<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In 1989 a short-lived low alcohol version of ''Webster's Yorkshire Bitter'' was launched, called ''Webster's XL''.<ref>Packaging: A taste of LA â After years of stagnation, the low and no alcohol market is slowly gathering strength, Marketing, 12 April 1990</ref>
==Advertising== [[File:Geograph - Harden.jpg|thumb|A former Webster's public house, still sporting the brewery's livery.]] Webster's utilized local television advertising for ''Green Label'' from 1961-66, with animated films featuring the character of "Wee Sam".<ref>The Times, 14 March 1967, p16</ref> In 1964 the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' theme composer [[Ron Grainer]] created the "Wee Sam Theme" that was used in the advertisements.<ref>SAMUEL WEBSTER & SONS LIMITED (Brewers, Maltsters, Wine & Spirit Merchants & Bottlers): All previous records surpassed CONSIDERABLY INCREASED SALES IN EVERY DEPARTMENT Mr. J. R. G. Marchetti on the year's development The Guardian (1959-2003) [London (UK)] 05 Mar 1965: 18.</ref> Advertising was extended from [[Associated British Corporation]] to include [[Granada Television]] from 1967.<ref name="Samuel Webster pg. 11">Samuel Webster & Sons Ltd. The Financial Times (London, England), Tuesday, 14 March 1967; p. 11; Edition 24,182.</ref> In the 1963 film ''[[This Sporting Life]]'' the slogan ''"Try Webster's Velvet Stout"'' is visible on the side of the [[rugby league|rugby]] ground stand, which was filmed at [[Wakefield]]'s [[Belle Vue (Wakefield)|Belle Vue]] rugby stadium.<ref>[http://www.flickr.com/photos/japaneseforms/4058517784/ try webster's velvet stout | Flickr - Photo Sharing!<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''Webster's Pennine Bitter'' had a number of memorable advertising campaigns. Perhaps its best known slogan was ''"Drives out the northern thirst"'' first used in 1970 and supported throughout the 1970s by a local television campaign featuring Yorkshire cricketer [[Fred Trueman]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.morningadvertiser.co.uk/news.ma/article/30119?Ntt=webster's%2Bbitter&Ntk=All&PagingData=Po_0~Ps_10~Psd_Asc |title=On the trail of old favourites |publisher=Morning Advertiser |date= |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref><ref>[http://www.barnsleycamra.org.uk/thebar/1997/spring-1997.pdf spring-1997.pdf<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In the advertisements, Trueman would breathe fire after drinking his pint of ''Pennine Bitter'' and say ''"We like things right in Yorkshire â like our beer. Webster's Pennine Bitter. Drives out the northern thirst."''<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2003/sep/23/thefiver.sport?INTCMP=SRCH | location=London | work=The Guardian | first1=Lawrence | last1=Booth | first2=Scott | last2=Murray | title=Previous and next, andFirst and last | date=23 September 2003}}</ref> The ''Halifax Courier'' commented, "quite how the northern thirst was different to the southern equivalent was never explained by the TV ads and billboards."<ref>[http://www.halifaxcourier.co.uk/lifestyle/columnists/surely_more_than_a_brand_1_1922524 Surely more than a brand? - Columnists - Halifax Courier<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> From 1979 the slogan ran: ''"Drink the Pennine way."''<ref> Management services, Volume 29, p30</ref> The actor [[Peter Davison]] followed as spokesman for ''Pennine Bitter'' until 1981.<ref name=autogenerated2>Advertising: Bygones, Marketing 22 August 1991</ref> Davison was forced to depart when he acquired the titular role of ''Doctor Who'' when the [[Independent Broadcasting Authority]] deemed it inappropriate for him to advertise beer whilst appearing in a programme that appealed to children.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
''Webster's Yorkshire Bitter'' was launched in 1982 with a Yorkshire-only television campaign that urged viewers to ''"Watch out for Webbo!"''. It continued to run until 1984. The comedian [[Charlie Williams (comedian)|Charlie Williams]] appeared in television advertisements for ''Yorkshire Bitter'' in 1984-85, which were the first adverts to showcase the new (and current) ''Webster's Yorkshire Bitter'' logo.<ref>[http://www.arrowsarchive.com/asset.pl?asset_id=279033 Arrows Archive<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One of the Williams advertisements featured a cameo from Yorkshire cricketers Fred Trueman and [[Ray Illingworth]]. The ''Webster's Yorkshire Bitter'' "Talking horses" campaign ran from 1986 until 1992 with the slogan ''"It's right tasty is Webster's"''.<ref>[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rgcw6frAeC8 WEBSTERS YORKSHIRE BITTER - FERRETS 1989 - YouTube<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Real [[dray horse]]s were used during the 1980s, but sophisticated [[animatronic]] puppets were used during the 1990s.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Between 1986â1988 Â£6.5 million was spent on advertising the brand; this was upped to Â£2 million each year for 1989 and 1990, and upped to Â£3 million in 1991.<ref>WAHT in first Webster's TV ads, Campaign, 24 October 1986</ref><ref>The Grocer, 7 November 1987</ref><ref>The Top 500 Brands Marketing February 1989</ref><ref>The top 500 brands, Marketing, 1 March 1990</ref><ref>The top 500 brands: Tesco's spend rockets, but most of the rest slump / A report on how the UK's big 500 brands are coping, Marketing, 7 March 1991</ref> In 1992 the spend was reduced to Â£400,000, although this was still enough to make ''Webster's Yorkshire Bitter'' the tenth most advertised beer brand on television.<ref>The good beer ad guide, Evening Standard, 31 March 1993</ref> The advertisements were an attempt to win back young drinkers who were increasingly drinking lager.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref>New Campaigns: TV, Campaign, 7 December 1990</ref> They were ineffective however, as research found that drinkers found the campaign "at best, safe and boring and, at worst, offensive".<ref name=JohnSmiths>[http://www.warc.com/Content/ContentViewer.aspx?MasterContentRef=e0761b8e-8836-42b5-8377-46386da78fb1&q=john+smiths John Smiths] warc.com {{subscription required}}</ref> The current slogan is ''"Perfect beers"'', a reversion to a slogan originally used from the 1920s until the 1960s.<ref name="freepages.history.rootsweb.ancestry.com"/><ref>[http://freepages.history.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~calderdalecompanion/ph1115.html Malcolm Bull's Calderdale Companion: Photograph<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Sponsorship=== Under the influence of Tommy Marchetti the company sponsored [[The HallÃ©]] orchestra to appear in Halifax to sell out audiences in 1966 and 1967.<ref name="Samuel Webster pg. 11"/> ''[[The Guardian]]'' commented that their description of the venture as "Ale and Arty" was insufficient to deter it from running for a second year.<ref>Continuing 'ale and arty' Parkin, Michael. The Guardian (1959-2003) [London (UK)] 29 Mar 1966: 5.</ref> In the summer of 1984 ''Webster's Yorkshire Bitter'' invested Â£100,000 into English cricket, with the aim of finding six fast bowlers by winter.<ref>Bailey, Trevor. "Search for a New Trueman." Financial Times [London, England] 11 August 1984: 13. Financial Times. 19 August 2011.</ref> From 1986 to 1992 Webster's sponsored the [[Bradford Bulls]] [[rugby league]] team, [[Dinnington Colliery Band]] from 1987 to 1990, the [[UK Open (darts)|UK Open]] [[darts]] championship in 1989 and 1990, and the [[World Matchplay (darts)|World Matchplay]] darts tournament in 1995 and 1996.<ref>WEBSTER'S ENTERS SECOND YEAR OF OPEN DARTS SPONSORSHIP, PR Newswrire Europe, 4 December 1990</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibew.org.uk/misc25.htm |title=The Internet Bandsman's Everything Within |publisher=IBEW |date= |accessdate=2011-05-07}}</ref> Webster's also invested in sponsorships at several racecourses from the early 1970s until the early 1990s.{{cn|date=November 2011}} In addition to this, they also supported other smaller sporting competitions, events and societies throughout Yorkshire.
